title: 105_s2258
content: For the purposes of this section, a "joint resolution" refers to a resolution introduced within 5 session days of Congress receiving a report. The resolution approves the President's recommendation to not apply a country sanction described in the report. The joint resolution approves the President's recommendation to remove a country sanction described in a report, with the appropriate date filled in. Resolutions introduced in the Senate go to the Committee on Foreign Relations, while those in the House of Representatives go to the Committee on International Relations. If a committee has not reported on a resolution, it may be discharged. If a resolution described in subsection (a) is not reported within 5 session days of Congress after its introduction, the committee is discharged from further consideration. Any member of the respective House can then move to proceed to the consideration of the resolution, with all points of order waived. The motion is highly privileged in the House of Representatives. The motion to proceed to the consideration of the resolution is highly privileged in the House of Representatives and privileged in the Senate. It is not debatable, amendable, or subject to postponement. A motion to reconsider the vote is not allowed. Debate on the resolution is limited to 8 hours, divided equally between those in favor and those opposing. Further debate limitations are allowed but not debatable. The motion to proceed to the consideration of the resolution is privileged and not debatable, amendable, or subject to postponement. A motion to reconsider the vote is not allowed. Following the debate, a vote on final passage of the resolution shall occur. Appeals from the Chair's decisions on procedural rules shall be decided without debate. If one House passes a resolution described in subsection (a), the other House's resolution is treated accordingly. If one House receives a resolution from the other House, certain procedures apply: the resolution is not referred to a committee, the House receiving the resolution follows its own procedures but votes on the other House's resolution for final passage. Upon receiving a veto message from the President, the House of origin considers the objections. Upon receiving a veto message from the President, the House of origin considers the objections and proceeds to immediate reconsideration of the joint resolution, regardless of the President's objections. After receiving a veto message from the President, the House of origin immediately considers objections and can proceed to reconsider the joint resolution. Motion to refer the resolution to a committee is not allowed. Any Member can move to proceed to reconsider the resolution, which is highly privileged in the House of Representatives and a question of highest privilege in the Senate. The motion is not debatable, amendable, or subject to postponement. The motion to proceed to reconsider the resolution is highly privileged and not debatable. Debate on the reconsideration of the joint resolution is limited to 8 hours, divided equally between those in favor and those opposing. Amendments, postponements, or consideration of other business are not allowed. Reconsidering the vote on the joint resolution is permitted despite the President's objections. The motion to reconsider the resolution is not debatable and limited to 8 hours of debate. Following the debate, a vote to override the President's objections must occur. This section is enacted by Congress as part of the rules of each House. The rules of each House can be changed by a resolution, superseding other rules if inconsistent. Each House has the constitutional right to change its rules at any time. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, "country sanction" refers to restrictions on Federal funds or property transactions involving a specific foreign country or government. "Mandated by statute" means directions expressed in a statute, excluding provisions conferring discretion or authority. The term "initial imposition" refers to the first imposition of a sanction under a statute, while "sanctionable activity" pertains to the conduct that leads to the imposition of a country sanction. The term "session day of Congress" is defined as any day when the respective House of Congress is in session.
